This report was prepared by S. Tsukada,  Transport and Communications Division, 
South Asia Department.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During the 2003 Country  Strategy Program Mission of the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB), the Government of India (“the Government”) requested technical assistance (TA) for the 
development  of  a  national  highway  development  strategy  for  Post-National  Highway 
Development Program (NHDP).1 The ADB TA Fact-Finding  Mission2 visited India on 3–13 
March 2003 and conducted discussions with officials of the Department of Economic Affairs, 
Ministry of Road Transport and Highways (MORTH), and National Highway Authority of India 
(NHAI).  The Mission and the Government reached an understanding on the revision of the 
original scope of the TA from the formulation of a post-NHDP national highway development 
strategy to the development of a high-density corridor (HDC) development program (the HDC 
Program). Further discussions were held with these agencies in May, August, and November 
2003, on the implementing agency, institutional arrangements for implementation, and detailed 
scope of the TA.  The TA paper was prepared based on the understandings reached with the 
Government during these discussions. The TA was included in the 2003 country strategy and 
program (CSP)3 for India. The TA framework is attached in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  India’s economy has long suffered from a chronic lack of capacity in the national 
highway systems.  Of 58,211 kilometers (km) of national highways, 39% are still single-lane; 
59% are two lanes; and only 2% are four-lane highways, which is desirable for arterial national 
highways. Thus, the Government has launched a radical program of upgrading three key 
corridors: (i) the Golden Quadrilateral, connecting four major metropolitan cities in India; (ii) the 
East-West Corridor, connecting eastern and western ends of the country; and (iii) the North-
South  Corridor,  connecting  northern  and  southern  ends  of  the  country.  The  corridor 
development program extends for 13,000 km and cost the nation $13 billion. The NHDP aims  
to increase integration of the country by connecting four of its corners. ADB, in support of the 
NHDP,4 has provided three loans for 2000–2002 and will provide another two loans for 2003–
2004, with the total loan amount expected to reach $1.5 billion. The World Bank has been 
providing similar loan amounts for the NHDP with the expected amount of $1.5 billion to $2.0 
billion for the same period.   
 
3.  In March 2003, the HDC Program, which is comparable to the NHDP in scale of 
investments ($8 billion) and length (10,000 km), was announced by the Government. The HDC 
Program was for rehabilitating and widening the two lane or narrower corridors with an average 
daily traffic of more than 30,000 passenger car equivalent units. MORTH identified 38 HDCs 
qualified for the HDC Program, each ranging of 200–300 km.5 The HDC Program will start this 
year and will be completed in 7 years (including 2 years of construction).  
 
4.  Given the limited available public sector funds (i.e., the central road funds can not be 
made available for the HCD Program because they are already committed for the next 10 years 
for debt services associated with NHDP development), the Government has decided to adopt

2  
build-operate-transfer (BOT) scheme for the HDC development. However, because tolls can not 
be charged on a full cost recovery basis, the Government intends to provide a grant to cover a 
part of construction costs, to keep tolls at the level affordable for various groups of society, 
including  local  communities.  Under  the  scheme,  prospective  contractors  will  compete  for 
concessions for toll road operation. Contractors who claim the lowest grant will win the BOT 
bidding.  
 
5.  Successful implementation of the public-private partnership (PPP) program will require, 
as a prerequisite, the establishment of a policy and institutional framework conducive to private 
sector participation. Thus, MORTH issued in 1997 Guidelines for the Private Sector Participation 
in the Road Infrastructure, and took policy actions, including (i) according tax exemption status to 
BOT investors; (ii) indicating government commitment in all preparatory activities, including land 
acquisition and removal of utilities; (iii) enabling the Government to provide grants of up to 40% 
of the project cost; (iv) allowing foreign direct investments up to 100% equity participation; (v) 
allowing duty free import of modern high performance construction equipment; and (vi) amending 
the National Highway Act to authorize private sector investors to operate a part of the national 
highway system and collect tolls under Government regulation.  
 
6.  Another critical element of the institutional framework is the Government’s toll policy.  
The current policy is that, once the national highways are upgraded to four lanes, they will be 
converted to toll roads. The level of tolls is uniformly set by the Government for the national 
highways. Tolls are adjusted for inflation based on the whole sale price index every year for 
BOT sections and every 3 years for NHAI sections. The tolls are not set for the full cost 
recovery, but to cover operation and maintenance and a part of debt services.  
 
7.  The implementing agency is another crucial issue. Originally, MORTH was assigned to 
implement the HDC Program.  However, the Government has later delegated the task to NHAI, 
an agency better equipped for the PPP program. NHAI was empowered to form joint ventures 
with private sector investors, form special purpose vehicles, invest and lend the funds for such 
ventures, and raise funds through issuing debentures. 
 
8.  While NHAI has used PPP schemes for highway development in a number of projects, it 
has never undertaken BOT development of this magnitude, entailing 140-160 BOT investments. 
This will require, within NHAI, the establishment of a unit specializing in the HDC Program.  
    
9.  Based on the above framework, further discussions were held with the Government on 
how the HDC Program is to be implemented and in what manner ADB can assist with its 
process.  The possible framework of ADB assistance under consideration is as follows:  
 
(i)  Provision of TA. TA could be provided for defining institutional arrangements for 
program implementation, including organizational arrangements to be set up 
within NHAI, project management consultants, and financing mechanisms to 
facilitate project preparation and enhance the financial viability of BOT projects.  
 
(ii)  Engineering support facility. The HDC Program will require the establishment 
of a revolving fund that will enable NHAI to prepare projects in cost-effective 
manner, as the money spent for the project preparation will be recouped from 
BOT contractors and used again for other projects. Based on the 2003 CSP, 
discussion is under way for the possible provision of an engineering support loan 
for providing seed money for the revolving fund.

3 
(iii)  Sector loans. Once the TA is undertaken and the revolving fund is established, 
ADB would start processing a sector loan to help develop BOT projects. ADB 
would finance the public sector contribution of the construction cost, while the 
rest of the construction cost and the operation and maintenance cost would be 
covered by the private sector.  Once the sector loan is included in the CSP, it is 
likely to lead to a series of lending for the highway sector, similar in scale to the  
NHDP. ADB’s intervention would cover one third or one fourth of the Program 
cost.   
 
(iv)  ADB assistance through private sector operations. ADB can provide partial 
credit guarantees which do not require sovereign counter guarantees to private 
sector financiers to facilitate borrowings by BOT contractors. ADB could also 
consider  providing  debt  and  equity  investments  in  BOT  contractors.  Such 
investments would require discussions with the Government, which has shown 
interest in these private sector financing and guarantee schemes.  
 
10.  The TA is an integral part of the package of assistance noted in para. 9, covering the 
initial stage of the development. The provision of the TA in a timely manner is critical for the 
successful implementation of the HDC Program.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
11.  The purpose of the TA is to facilitate the implementation of the HDC Program by (i) 
establishing  institutional  arrangements  necessary  for  project  management  and  financing 
mechanisms, and (ii) elaborating the concept of the entire HDC Program to provide an overall 
plan for its implementation.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The TA will have five components: 
 
(i)  Institutional arrangements.  The first component will (i) develop institutional 
arrangements needed for the efficient delivery of the overall program, and (ii) 
define those key concepts such as the “revolving fund for project preparation 
facility” and the “capital investment grant fund” (Appendix 3). 
 
(ii)  Traffic projection and prioritization.  The second component will support  (i) 
reviewing  the  current  traffic  projections  for  individual  HDCs,  completed  by 
MORTH; (ii) developing a traffic forecast methodology to be applied for the HDC 
Program and, based on the methodology, forecasting traffic for each HDC; (iii) 
taking stock of current road conditions (particularly road roughness), right of way 
availability, and environmental and social impediments; and (iv) based on these 
analyses,  prioritizing  investments  and  developing  a  time  table  for  the  HDC 
Program implementation. 
 
(iii)  PPP investment schemes. The third component will support (i) reviewing the 
PPP schemes such as annuity-based concession, toll-based BOT, and special 
purpose  vehicles,  and  comparing  their  relative  merits;  (ii)  recommending 
appropriate forms of PPP schemes to be applied for HDC development, including

4  
a BOT scheme with grant provision from NHAI and annuity-based concession 
with tolling right to be transferred to the concessionaire; (iii) developing the 
appropriate modality for ADB lending through its public sector window, to fit the 
operating principles set out in ADB’s Charter; and (iv) if needed, recommending 
modifications to the current model contract documents for the PPP. 
 
(iv)  Program  design.  The  fourth  component  would  design  a  structure  for  ADB 
financing of part of the HDC Program, under the sector loan modality. ADB’s 
intervention would cover one third or one fourth of the HDC Program to be 
managed by a project management consultant or one chief general manager. 
The tasks include (i) recommending to NHAI the subprogram to be covered by a 
series of ADB sector loans; (ii) developing the concepts for each HDC under the 
subprogram;  (iii)  identifying  HDCs  to  be  included  in  the  sector  loan;  (iv) 
conducting initial environmental screening for each HDC to be selected; and (v) 
conducting the sector environmental assessment and developing road safety 
standards and necessary activities to be included in the sector loan.  
 
(v)  Social safeguards.  The fifth component will cover (i) an initial poverty and 
social assessment for each HDC in the subprogram, in accordance with ADB’s 
Guidelines on Initial Poverty and Social Assessment; (ii) initial screening for 
involuntary  resettlement  and  indigenous  peoples  by  filling  out  the  relevant 
checklists; (iii) a resettlement framework and indigenous people development 
framework, to be prepared in accordance with ADB’s policy.   
 
13.  Components (i)–(iv) will be carried out by a consulting firm and component (v) will be 
carried  out  by  individual  consultants.    Where  conducting  components  (iv)  and  (v),  the 
consultants will refer to the work which done during the preparation and processing of the 
National Highway Corridor (Sector) I Project. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $900,000 equivalent, comprising $574,100 in 
foreign exchange costs and $325,900 equivalent in local currency costs. ADB will provide 
$700,000 equivalent on a grant basis, to finance the entire foreign exchange cost of $574,100 
and $125,900 equivalent of local currency costs. The TA will be financed on a grant basis from 
the Japan Special Fund, funded by the Government of Japan. The Government will finance the 
remaining  $200,000  equivalent  of  the  local  currency  costs,  which  will  include  office 
accommodation, counterpart staff remuneration, communication, transportation, and surveys. 
The cost estimates and financing plan are detailed in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  NHAI  will  be  the  Executing  Agency.  By  January  2004,  NHAI  will  establish  a  TA  
implementation unit that will be the focal point for implementing the TA.  
 
16.  ADB  will  engage  a  consulting  firm,  using  ADB’s  quality-  and  cost-based  selection 
procedures with the simplified technical proposal. The task will require 18 person-months input 
of international and 8 person-months input of domestic consultants. ADB will also engage two 
individual consultants, one international and one domestic. The selection of the consulting firm 
and  individual  will  be  carried  out  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of

5 
Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB on the selection and engagement of 
domestic consultants.  
 
17.  The TA will commence in January 2004 and be closed in December 2004.  Terms of 
reference (TOR) for the consulting firm are outlined in Appendix 3. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding $700,000 on a grant basis to the Government of 
India, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

8  Appendix 3 
TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
A.  Components 1–4 
1.  Team of Experts. The consulting firm will form a team of eight experts with the following 
qualifications: 
 
(i)  International transport economist. The economist will have had (a) experience 
in public-private partnership (PPP) projects in the highway sector; (b) knowledge 
of highway development in the South Asia Region; (c) knowledge of the policy 
and procedural requirements of multilateral aid agencies such as the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) or the World Bank; and (d) preferably, knowledge on 
the India’s consulting and construction industries. The economist will lead the 
consultant team.   
 
(ii)  International  project  finance  specialist.  The  specialist  will  have  had  (a) 
extensive first-hand experience with build-operate-transfer (BOT) schemes or 
similar private sector participation (PSP) schemes, in the transport sector; and 
(b) broad experience in implementing BOT or PSP projects, knowing the whole 
process  of  processing  PSP  projects,  including  conceptualization,  bidding, 
negotiation, and financial closure. Adequate knowledge on India’s financial sector 
(banking,  infrastructure  financing,  credit  rating,  India’s  capital  markets)  is 
preferable.  
 
(iii)  International transport specialist. The specialist will have had (a) extensive 
experience working for the multilateral aid agencies such as ADB and WB; and 
(b)  knowledge  of  traffic  projection,  particularly  on  toll  roads,  which  require 
demand forecast for with and without toll scenarios; and (c) extensive experience 
organizing traffic counts, compiling traffic data, and conducting traffic projection. 
 
(iv)  International  environmental  specialist.  The  specialist  will  have  had  (a) 
extensive experience working for multilateral aid agencies such as ADB and WB; 
and (b) knowledge of the safeguard policies of these agencies in the area of 
environment; and (c) knowledge of Indian Government requirements on the 
environment. 
 
(v)  International road safety specialist. The specialist will have had extensive 
experience  assisting  developing  countries  in  road safety. Extensive working 
experience with multilateral aid agencies such as ADB and WB is preferable. 
Areas  of  particular  importance  are  the  enforcement  of  traffic  regulation, 
emergency road services, road signage, highway design for road safety, and 
road safety audit and traffic engineering.  
 
(vi)  Domestic financial analyst. The analyst will have had extensive experience in 
financial analysis and model development for financing of infrastructure sector 
projects.   
 
(vii)  Domestic environmental specialist. The specialist will have had extensive 
experience in environmental assessment of highway development projects in 
India, and should had extensive experience in field surveys.

Appendix 3  9 
(viii)  Domestic  transport  specialist.  The  specialist  will  have  had  extensive 
experience organizing traffic counts, compiling traffic data, and conducting traffic 
projections.  
 
2.  Scope of Work. The team of experts will carry out the following tasks: 
 
  (i)  Development of institutional arrangements:  
 
(a)  The  implementation  of  this  magnitude  of  the  HDC  Program  requires 
systematic preparation of individual projects (likely to total 140–160). This 
will require the establishment of institutional arrangements for the efficient 
implementation of the high density corridor (HDC) Program.   
(b)  The implementation of the above HDC Program would also require the 
establishment  of  a  revolving  fund  to  enable  the  National  Highways 
Authority of India (NHAI) to prepare projects in a cost-effective manner, 
as the money spent for project preparation will be recouped from BOT 
contractors and reused for other projects.  The Consultants are required 
to elaborate the concept of  the “revolving fund for project preparation 
facility,” describe how the revolving fund is to be structured and managed, 
and estimate resource requirements. The task includes the estimation of 
the  appropriate  level  of  charges  by  NHAI  to  the  successful  BOT 
contractors. The charges should include the cost of project preparation, 
including the resettlement plan, environmental assessment, and other 
reasonable activities to be born by the BOT contractors.   
(c)  Given that the HDCs have been used for decades with no tolls being 
charged, but will be converted into toll roads with the level of tolls being 
controlled by the Government regulations, the private sector can not 
develop, operate, and maintain the roads without public sector support. 
HDCs are, therefore, envisaged to be carried out as PPP. The possible 
PPP  schemes  include  the  government  provision  of  a  grant  to  BOT 
contractors to cover part of the construction costs, paid as a lump-sum 
basis or in tranches. Since a number of BOT/concession projects are 
being implemented simultaneously during 5–6 years, a pool of grants to 
be paid to the contractors at different construction stages, should be 
considered.  The  consultants  will  elaborate  the  concept  of  the  capital 
investment  fund  and  describe  how  the  fund  is  to  be  structured  and 
managed.  
 
(ii)  Traffic projection and prioritization.  
 
(a)  The Ministry of Road Transport and Highways has forecast traffic for most 
of the HDCs, but much data needs to be verified and updated by the 
consultants.  The  traffic  forecast  should  cover  normal,  diverted,  and 
generated traffic. The diverted traffic should be estimated on the basis of 
the  network  analysis.  Traffic  projection  should  be  done  for  with  and 
without toll scenarios. 
(b)  The consultants should inventory all HDCs with regard to road conditions 
(particularly road roughness), right-of-way availability, environmental and 
social impediments, etc. 
(c)  Based on the analyses, the consultants should prioritize the investments 
for HDCs, and develop a time table for developing the corridor.

10  Appendix 3 
 
(iii)  Public-private partnership scheme development: 
 
(a)  The consultants will review the PPP schemes which have been used by 
NHAI, such as annuity-based concession, toll-based BOT, and special 
purpose vehicles, and comparing their relative merits.  
(b)  The consultants will develop appropriate forms of PPP schemes to be 
applied  for  HDC  development,  including  a  BOT  scheme  with  grant 
provision from NHAI and annuity-based concession with tolling right to be 
transferred to the concessionaire. 
(c)  The consultants will also develop an appropriate lending modality under 
for ADB to assist PPP projects through its pubic sector financing window.  
The  proposed  PPP  lending  modality  should  be  in  line  with  ADB’s 
operating principles, particularly that of “drawing the funds only to meet 
expenditures as they are actually incurred.” 
(d)  The consultants will, if needed, recommend modifications to the current 
model contract documents developed by the Government for the PPP. 
 
(iv)  Program design: 
 
(a)  The  consultants  will:  (i)  determine  with  NHAI,  the  subprogram  to  be 
covered by a series of ADB sector loans; (ii) develop project concepts for 
the individual HDCs to be covered by the subprogram; (iii) design the 
structure of the BOT scheme best suited for each project; (iv) conduct 
environmental  screening  for  all  subprojects  to  be  included  in  the 
subprogram,  and  develop  sector  environmental  assessment  for  the 
subprogram,  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  current  environmental 
assessment  guidelines;  (v)  develop  a  set  of  performance  monitoring 
indicators to be used for evaluating the impact of the subprogram; and (vi) 
develop road safety standards and necessary activities to be included in 
all subprojects to enhance road safety. 
 
3.  The international transport economist will be the team leader and will organize and 
manage  the  entire  work  program.  The  task  will  require  5  person-months  of  input  by  the 
international  transport  economist,  5  by  the  international  project  finance  analyst,  4  by  the 
international  transport  specialist,  2  by  the  international  environmental  specialist,  2  by 
international highway engineer, and 1 by the road safety specialist. In addition, 3 person-months 
will  be  needed  by  the  domestic  financial  analyst,  and  2  by  the  domestic  environmental 
specialist, and 2 by domestic social development specialist.  
 
4.   Time table. The implementation schedule is as follows: 
 
(i)  an inception report by the end of February 2004, 
(ii)  a draft report on the institutional arrangement component by the end of  March 
2004, 
(iii)  a draft report on the traffic forecast and prioritization by the end of June 2004, 
and 
(iv)  a draft report on the program design component by the end of August 2004.

B.  Component 5 
 
5.  Team of Experts. To carry out the component, one international resettlement specialist 
and one domestic social development specialist will be engaged. Key requirement for the 
specialists are as follows:      
 
(i)  The resettlement specialist: He/she should be familiar with the process of land 
acquisition and resettlement in India. He/she should have more than five years of 
experience working for these areas. Key requirements are familiarity with ADB’s 
policy and procedural requirements for resettlements and extensive involvement 
in ADB financed highway projects.  
(ii)  The social development specialist: He/she should be familiar with the process 
of  social  development  issues  including:  HIV/AIDS,  indigenous  people 
development, women/children trafficking, and gender issues. He/she should have 
more than three years’ of working experience in these areas.  A key requirement 
is familiarity with policy and procedural requirements of ADB and/or the World 
Bank.   
 
6.  Scope of Work. The scope of work is as follows: 
 
(i)  Resettlement.  The  international  resettlement  specialist  will  carry  out  the 
following tasks: 
 
(a)  Review  and  evaluate  the  effectiveness  of  the  current  organizational 
arrangements  for  land  acquisition  and  resettlement,  including  NHAI’s 
experience in monitoring the implementation of the resettlement plan and 
adequacy of human resources of environment and social development 
unit.  Based  on  this  assessment  and  if  necessary,  develop 
recommendations for strengthening NHAI’s capacity to implement the 
activities. 
(b)  Conduct an initial poverty and social assessment in accordance with 
ADB’s guidelines.  
(c)  Conduct  initial  screening  for  involuntary  resettlement  and  indigenous 
people by filling out the appropriate checklists. 
(d)  Develop a resettlement framework in accordance with ADB’s policy.   
 
(ii)  Social development. The domestic social development specialists will carry out 
the following tasks: 
 
(a)  Conduct  necessary  surveys  on  emerging  social  issues,  including 
HIV/AIDS, trafficking of women and children, and gender issues. 
(b)  Develop the indigenous people development framework to be applied for 
all projects.
